commit_message:
Introduce a simple state machine module

States are used in an ad-hoc fashion all over Nova codebase. It's high
time we added some code that will let us define and abstract basic
operations with state changes.

This commit adds 2 classes that will be used to define the state graph,
and a simple way to step through the state graph. For this we use the
"automaton" library, that is already in uses by several other OpenStack
projects for similar purposes.

Class State is holds a state-space and a name of the state, and a list
of states that we could go from it. Each State instance references 0
or more other states within the same state-space as it's next_states
attribute thus creating a directed graph.

Class FSM represents a state machine, and is a slightly customized
version of the automaton FiniteMachine class that when given a
state-space, builds a graph of all known states and it's transitions,
and also exposes a step() method that will either progress the machine
to a new state or raise an error if the transition is not valid for the
given state-space.

Related-blueprint: migration-fix-resource-tracking
Change-Id: Ic3c9dbd4af8fe92499d84d43ca3e48783f3a59de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/68/197668/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import collections import six from nova import exception class _MustBeDefined(Exception): pass _StateRegistry = collections.namedtuple("_StateRegistry", ["name_registry", "object_registry"]) def _new_registry(): return _StateRegistry(name_registry={}, object_registry={}) class State(object): _registry = collections.defaultdict(_new_registry) def __new__(cls, namespace, name_or_state, next_states=None, defined=False): name_reg, obj_reg = cls._registry[namespace] if isinstance(name_or_state, cls): lookup_reg = obj_reg elif isinstance(name_or_state, six.string_types): lookup_reg = name_reg if name_or_state in lookup_reg: return lookup_reg[name_or_state] else: if defined: raise _MustBeDefined() if isinstance(name_or_state, cls): obj = name_or_state elif isinstance(name_or_state, six.string_types): obj = object.__new__(cls) obj.space_name = namespace obj.name = name_or_state obj.next_states = next_states or [] name_reg[obj.name] = obj obj_reg[obj] = obj return obj def __unicode__(self): return self.name def RegisteredState(namespace, name_or_state): try: return State(namespace, name_or_state, defined=True) except _MustBeDefined: raise exception.InvalidState(state=name_or_state) class States(object): def __init__(self, space, initial_state, current_state): self.space = space self.initial_state = RegisteredState(self.space, initial_state) self.states = set([]) self._discover_graph() self.set(current_state) def _discover_graph(self): def _visit_state(state): if state in self.states: return self.states.add(state) for next_state in state.next_states: _visit_state(next_state) _visit_state(self.initial_state) def step(self, new_state=None): new_state = new_state and RegisteredState(self.space, new_state) next_states = self.state.next_states if new_state and new_state in next_states: self.state = new_state elif not new_state and len(next_states) == 1: self.state = next_states[0] else: raise exception.InvalidStateTransition(state=self.state, new_state=new_state) return self.state def set(self, new_state): new_state = RegisteredState(self.space, new_state) if new_state not in self.states: raise exception.InvalidState(state=new_state) self.state = new_state

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-10-08 22:09:08.000000000', 'files': ['.gitignore', '.fixtures.yml', 'Rakefile', 'Gemfile'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron/commit/ee10d14987a96fb82cc0905827f7891e8e6ecbb8', 'message': "Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

In OpenStack Infra, we would like to run Puppet unit tests that
sometimes depends on other Puppet OpenStack modules.
Example: a patch in puppet-openstacklib that needs to be tested in puppet-nova.

This patch modifies the Rakefile to:
* clean spec_prep and spec_clean Rake tasks
* use openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/install_modules_unit.sh script
  to clone modules.
* do not use .fixtures.yaml file to clone modules and rely on
  zuul-cloner or git.
* Add openstack/ in gitignore so we never commit the
  puppet-openstack-integration repository (can happen when spec_clean
  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross
modules like we do with functional testing.

Change-Id: I555bdeba198b1b468884ffce3702f5b06247d573
"}]
commit_message:
Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

In OpenStack Infra, we would like to run Puppet unit tests that
sometimes depends on other Puppet OpenStack modules.
Example: a patch in puppet-openstacklib that needs to be tested in puppet-nova.

This patch modifies the Rakefile to:
* clean spec_prep and spec_clean Rake tasks
* use openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/install_modules_unit.sh script
  to clone modules.
* do not use .fixtures.yaml file to clone modules and rely on
  zuul-cloner or git.
* Add openstack/ in gitignore so we never commit the
  puppet-openstack-integration repository (can happen when spec_clean
  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross
modules like we do with functional testing.

Change-Id: I555bdeba198b1b468884ffce3702f5b06247d573
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/82/232782/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: gem 'r10k', :require => 'false'

commit_message:
Remove openstack_deploy from teardown.sh deletion list

This patch prevents teardown.sh script from deleting
/etc/openstack_deploy in order to let the deployer decide whether to
delete it or not.

Change-Id: I8de55c6fce79bd9301d995c565cfb4e0a38b253a
Closes-Bug: #1504561
(cherry picked from commit 6f21ceb86559f9d2c0f0bc765b1602e79cbd10f6)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/24/233224/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: removed from the host as well. /etc/openstack_deploy will be preserved and may be manually removed if needed.
deleted_lines: removed from the host as well, including all configuration data within /etc/openstack_deploy/. - /etc/openstack_deploy

commit_message:
Make bootstrap-ansible script compatible with RHEL

This patch enables the bootstrap-ansible.sh script to also work on RHEL
and other "yum" based Linux distributions.

Change-Id: I3e28f4f4f09e7387c97afc219899bba1927215e8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/65/232165/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: APT=`command -v apt-get` || true YUM=`command -v yum` || true if [[ "$APT" != "" ]]; then apt-get update && apt-get -y install git python-all python-dev curl autoconf g++ python2.7-dev elif [[ "$YUM" != "" ]]; then yum check-update && yum -y install git python2 curl autoconf gcc-c++ python2-devel fi
deleted_lines: apt-get update && apt-get -y install git python-all python-dev curl autoconf g++ python2.7-dev

commit_message:
py34: cleanup

* Tests were skipped due to a mox3 bug. The bug has now been fixed
  and there's a new release of mox3. Unskip it.
* Remove the tool run-py3-tests.sh which isn't needed anymore.

blueprint heat-python34-support

Change-Id: I304d87e4313148c10a2465bf92ae932f525bb4ce

  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross
modules like we do with functional testing.

Change-Id: I42fb3d11d65e261bd5fb0ccb757a68965699a693
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ironic refs/changes/77/232777/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: gem 'r10k', :require => 'false'

commit_message:
Only get host data for floating ips on DVR routers

First, we are only interested in setting the host attribute when
the router is a DVR router.  Second, we don't need to query all of
the ports on the host, we just need to query the ports that are
referenced by the set of floating ips that we already have.

(cherry picked from commit 3c5cb9d050d09424c3f8eb3cd1ecd6876f50a6fe)

Closes-bug: #1496974
Change-Id: If611de14b2ab77d2eb9ce8c5b307ea6dd4403fe1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/16/233116/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: dvr_router_ids = set(router['id'] for router in routers if is_distributed_router(router)) floating_ip_port_ids = [fip['port_id'] for fip in floating_ips if fip['router_id'] in dvr_router_ids] if floating_ip_port_ids: port_filter = {portbindings.HOST_ID: [host], 'id': floating_ip_port_ids} ports = self._core_plugin.get_ports(context, port_filter) port_dict = dict((port['id'], port) for port in ports) # Add the port binding host to the floatingip dictionary for fip in floating_ips: vm_port = port_dict.get(fip['port_id'], None) if vm_port: fip['host'] = self.get_vm_port_hostid(context, fip['port_id'], port=vm_port)
deleted_lines: port_filter = {portbindings.HOST_ID: [host]} ports = self._core_plugin.get_ports(context, port_filter) port_dict = dict((port['id'], port) for port in ports) # Add the port binding host to the floatingip dictionary for fip in floating_ips: vm_port = port_dict.get(fip['port_id'], None) if vm_port: fip['host'] = self.get_vm_port_hostid(context, fip['port_id'], port=vm_port)

commit_message:
Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

In OpenStack Infra, we would like to run Puppet unit tests that
sometimes depends on other Puppet OpenStack modules.
Example: a patch in puppet-openstacklib that needs to be tested in puppet-nova.

This patch modifies the Rakefile to:
* clean spec_prep and spec_clean Rake tasks
* use openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/install_modules_unit.sh script
  to clone modules.
* do not use .fixtures.yaml file to clone modules and rely on
  zuul-cloner or git.
* Add openstack/ in gitignore so we never commit the
  puppet-openstack-integration repository (can happen when spec_clean
  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross
modules like we do with functional testing.

Change-Id: I7b5af3ea6b21009a505a8b6c49086d339eaa43e5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-horizon refs/changes/76/232776/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: gem 'r10k', :require => 'false'

commit_message:
Change os-url to os-auth-url on call to OSC

A change was made to the openstackclient that allows the --os-url
switch to be used only when --os-token is used. As we removed the
use of --os-token a while back, we need to switch to using
--os-auth-url instead of --os-url.

Change-Id: Ia769cd4e07e845746adb10d5c25d5095623a8a32
Closes-bug: bug/1504303

commit_message:
Reduce size of CoreOS ramdisk

By disabling pip cache, we're able to reduce the size of generated
docker image by 10%. The resulting ramdisk size goes from 229MB to
218MB.

It is possible to decrease the size even further by combining all the
RUN instructions into one but it doesn't provide a substantial gain and
it harms readability.

Change-Id: Ie23636fe709ab7c1bcf4d6c51299c173a5b642ac

commit_message:
Move yum-based install into function

Move yum-based install into a function, to make way for a second
related function where use dnf later

commit_message:
Use puppet to configure ironic-inspector

This removes the ironic-inspector element from the
undercloud install, and instead uses the puppet module
to setup the ironic-inspector service.

Depends-On: I9b2917a2c3f6afe75dc295c81d09f7a12856007f
Change-Id: Ic3eca27515721000ed1c9d19a2427276e6b1af68

added_lines: ironic::inspector::dnsmasq_local_ip: {{LOCAL_IP}} ironic::inspector::dnsmasq_ip_range: {{INSPECTION_IPRANGE}} ironic::inspector::dnsmasq_interface: {{INSPECTION_INTERFACE}}

Added sample conf instructions to resolve errors

Purpose: help users avoid common errors in stand-alone install
Changes: Added instructions for upgrading virtualenv to resolve
 common errors

Change-Id: Iac2a7a18511198feb50642dab46db4492ee0e777

added_lines: command from the top level of the congress directory (may need root privilege): tox -egenconfig #Generates etc/congress.conf.sample If tox is not installed, install and upgrade related tools: $ sudo pip install --upgrade pip virtualenv setuptools pbr tox If you had installed tox using apt-get and experience the following error: "ERROR: genconfig: could not install deps", you may be able to resolve the problem by re-installing tox as follows: $ sudo apt-get purge python-tox $ sudo pip install --upgrade pip virtualenv setuptools pbr tox $ sudo rm .tox -rf (Based on: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1486335/comments/12)

commit_message:
Switch to use `region_id` for endpoint APIs

`region` field is deprected in favor of `region_id` since keystone v3.2,
please refer to keystone v3 API spec [1].

[1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/api/v3/identity-api-v3.html#endpoints-v3-endpoints

Change-Id: I5d88449e3b0ac53093eba2d8157a620616d9769c

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-30 04:28:56.000000000', 'files': ['api-ref/src/wadls/orchestration-api/src/v1/orchestration-api.wadl'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/api-site/commit/ca9343ac212ad9427f1cff5b3211bcfe78f62e36', 'message': 'Remove confusing parameter description in heat API

commit_message:
Remove confusing parameter description in heat API

  At first, Current documentation is correct
  in programatically.
  But it makes confusing for user about "resource_name".
  This patch intends to remove confusing documentation.

  Of course, keep, or add notice for same parameter,
  are another option.

  #Detail#

  Event listing in heat uses common filtering engine.
  And its query parameter is common which includes
  "resouce_name"
  and some REST API uses resource_name in URL.

  its code is here
  heat/api/openstack/v1/events.py

Change-Id: Ie7030fb6ba15b6ee7e66fd3f39c03bed1f736782
Closes-Bug: #1500621
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/37/229237/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

You can use this filter multiple times to filter by multiple resource names. </para> </wadl:doc> </param> <param xmlns="http://wadl.dev.java.net/2009/02"

commit_message:
Fix obj_to_primitive() when using manifests (list version)

This is the logical continuation of a previous change:
I27b8a13dadc11b78c890b54eaeb9eb728125977a. That skipped the
equivalent change for the list objects, which this adds.

Change-Id: I6af7e792cc68ec1349026beee200494bae528625
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.versionedobjects refs/changes/65/233165/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_do_subobject_backport_list_object_with_manifest(self): child = self.ChildObj(foo=1) parent = self.ParentObjList(objects=[child]) manifest = {'ChildObj': '1.0', 'ParentObjList': '1.0'} parent_primitive = parent.obj_to_primitive(target_version='1.0', version_manifest=manifest) self.assertEqual('1.0', parent_primitive['versioned_object.version']) child_primitive = parent_primitive['versioned_object.data']['objects'] self.assertEqual('1.0', child_primitive[0]['versioned_object.version'])

can be safely done.

Partially implements: blueprint move-policy-engine

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-09 22:55:56.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/plugins.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/searchlight/commit/83ed8e723de91bd095aaa505fea41b49fd7532c1', 'message': "Document unsearchable_fields configuration option

Although RBAC prevents protected fields appearing in search results, it
cannot prevent searching those fields directly. A long term solution is
a separate admin-only index but for now we add a resource plugin option
'unsearchable_fields' which is comma separated and accepts wildcards as
elasticsearch's mapping_template allows. These fields are turned into
index: no, include_in_all: False mapping templates. The value of this
(plus anything coded into a plugin) is also used to redact fields in
_source for non-administrative users.

This patch provides the documentation update for:
 - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/233225/

Change-Id: I94f47515391cf81d72a6a0d09e7a554259a1f8fb
Partial-Bug: #1504399
(cherry picked from commit 0f1518e3d636045350df4a5e8dd8807530691359)
"}]
commit_message:
Document unsearchable_fields configuration option

Although RBAC prevents protected fields appearing in search results, it
cannot prevent searching those fields directly. A long term solution is
a separate admin-only index but for now we add a resource plugin option
'unsearchable_fields' which is comma separated and accepts wildcards as
elasticsearch's mapping_template allows. These fields are turned into
index: no, include_in_all: False mapping templates. The value of this
(plus anything coded into a plugin) is also used to redact fields in
_source for non-administrative users.

This patch provides the documentation update for:
 - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/233225/

Change-Id: I94f47515391cf81d72a6a0d09e7a554259a1f8fb
Partial-Bug: #1504399
(cherry picked from commit 0f1518e3d636045350df4a5e8dd8807530691359)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/searchlight refs/changes/03/233303/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: actions indicated in the tables below... note:: Unless you are changing to a non-default value, you do not need to specify any of the following configuration options. Common Plugin Configuration Options ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ There are common configuration options that all plugins honor. They are split between inheritable configuration options and those that must always be specified individually. **Inheritable Common Configuration Options** Some configuration options may be specified in a default configuration group of ``[resource_plugin]`` in ``searchlight-api.conf`` and optionally overridden in a specific plugin's configuration. For example:: [resource_plugin] index_name = searchlight Inheritable options are listed below: +---------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ | Option | Default value | Description | Action(s) Required | +=====================+===============+=====================================+===========================+ | index_name | searchlight | The ElasticSearch index where the | | Restart services | | | | plugin resource documents will be | | Re-index affected types | | | | stored in. It is recommended to not | | | | | change this unless needed. | | +---------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ **Non-Inheritable Common Configuration Options** There are other common configuration options that all plugins honor, but must be specified directly in that plugin's configuration group. They are are not inherited from the ``[resource_plugin]`` configuration group. See :ref:`individual-plugin-configuration` for more information and examples on individual plugin configuration. Non-inheritable options are listed below: +---------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ | Option | Default value | Description | Action(s) Required | +=====================+===============+=====================================+===========================+ | enabled | true | An installed plugin may be enabled | | Restart services | | | | or disabled. When disabled, it will | | Re-index affected types | | | | not be available for bulk indexing, | | | | | notification listening, or | | | | | searching. | | +---------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ | unsearchable_fields | <none> | A comma separated list of fields | | | | | (wildcards allowed) that are stored | | | | | in ElasticSearch, but can not be | | | | | searched on regardless of the | | | | | user's role (admin or not). | | | | | The fields will still be returned | | | | | in search results for admin users, | | | | | but not normal users. These fields | | | | | are typically specified for search | | | | | performance, search accuracy, | | | | | or security reasons. | | | | | If a plugin has a hard-coded | | | | | mapping for a specific field, it | | | | | will take precedence over this | | | | | configuration option. | | +---------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ .. _individual-plugin-configuration:
deleted_lines: Default Plugin Configuration ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ All plugins inherit their configuration from a default configuration group of ``[resource_plugin:default]`` in ``searchlight-api.conf``. For example:: [resource_plugin:default] enabled = true index_name = searchlight The below table shows the available default configuration options. It is only necessary to specify a configuration option in ``searchlight-api.conf`` if you want to use a value other than the default value specified below. +--------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ | Option | Default value | Description | Action(s) Required | +====================+===============+=====================================+===========================+ | enabled | true | An installed plugin may be enabled | | Restart services | | | | or disabled. When disabled, it will | | Re-index affected types | | | | not be available for bulk indexing, | | | | | notification listening, or | | | | | searching. | | +--------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ | index_name | searchlight | The ElasticSearch index where the | | Restart services | | | | plugin resource documents will be | | Re-index affected types | | | | stored in. It is recommended to not | | | | | change this unlesss needed. | | +--------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ actions indicated in the table. commit_message:
Added checking for invalid or malformed command line parameters

The parse_parameters function needed additional logic to recognize and
reject bad parameters.  Primarily, this fix assures that each
parameter is a valid assignment of the form 'a=b'.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1503515

Change-Id: I79d55359743f9c06fb006292fc61dae273e97eb8

commit_message:
Modify admin_api policy rule

Magnum API's magnum_service:get_all is enforced by admin_api.
Modifying the rule to use context_is_admin. Also changing the to_dict()
call to include change in roles.

Change-Id: I44dda27857945dfd3ad43fa28ea458ce2966388c
Closes-Bug: #1503402

commit_message:
WIP Functional test needs to have two types of user

At present, we are continuing the functional test with one user only,
which happens to be 'admin'. This defeats any test based on role, or
similar policy enforcement.

commit_message:
Remove _stop_instances hack in test_volume_boot_pattern

This was a carry over from when the test was originally written in
b3c3cb9c331e9ee54832326420ebe7ac4bf2e080 over 2 years ago.

We shouldn't have to stop the instances in order to delete them, that
would be a bug in nova if the delete failed for some reason because the
instances are still active.

Change-Id: I20b7c2e4c2b110933244ba65a1ccdbf246266946
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/92/222692/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Fix the condition of nova cert tests

Unskip baremetal api tests

test_update_port_mixed_ops,
test_create_port_with_extra.

commit_message:
Add VMEM v6000 block storage config page

Adds configuration reference page for Violin Memory's v6000 Cinder
block-storage driver.

Change-Id: I2217b79e8b8921e0c5cb3efe151527d3eacfffcc
backport: kilo
Closes-Bug: 1438940
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/88/233288/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <section xml:id="violin-v7000-driver" xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="5.0"> <title>Violin Memory 7000 series FSP Driver</title> <para> The OpenStack Cinder V7000 driver package from Violin Memory adds block-storage service support for Violin 7300 Flash Storage Platforms (FSPs) and 7700 FSP controllers. </para> <para> All Cinder volume features required for the OpenStack Liberty release are supported, including volume, snapshot and clone operations. The driver package release can be used with any OpenStack Liberty deployment for all 7300 FSPs and 7700 FSP controllers running Concerto 7.5.3 and later using Fibre Channel HBAs. </para> <section xml:id="violin-v7k-sys-reqs"> <title>System requirements</title> <para>To use the Violin driver, the following are required:</para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para>Violin 7300/7700 series FSP with: <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para>Concerto OS version 7.5.3 or later</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Fibre channel host interfaces</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> The Violin Cinder Driver: This driver implements the Cinder API calls. The driver is included with the OpenStack Liberty release. </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para> The vmemclient library: This is the Violin Array Communications library to the Flash Storage Platform through a REST-like interface. The client can be installed using the python 'pip' installer tool. Further information on vmemclient can be found here: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/vmemclient/. </para> <programlisting language="ini"> pip install vmemclient </programlisting> </listitem> </itemizedlist> </section> <section xml:id="violin-v7k-supported-ops"> <title>Supported operations</title> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para>Create, delete, attach, and detach volumes.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Create, list, and delete volume snapshots.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Create a volume from a snapshot.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Copy an image to a volume.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Copy a volume to an image.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Clone a volume.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Extend a volume.</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> <note> <para> Listed operations are supported for thick, thin, and dedup luns, with the exception of cloning. Cloning operations are supported only on thick luns. </para> </note> </section> <section xml:id="violin-v7k-driver-cfg"> <title>Driver configuration</title> <para> Once the array is configured per the installation guide, it is simply a matter of editing the cinder configuration file to add or modify the parameters. The driver currently only supports fibre channel configuration. </para> <section xml:id="vioin-v7k-fc-cfg"> <title>Fibre channel configuration</title> <para> Set the following in your <filename>cinder.conf</filename> configuration file, replacing the variables using the guide in the following section: </para> <programlisting language="ini"> volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.violin.v7000_fcp.V7000FCPDriver volume_backend_name = vmem_violinfsp extra_capabilities = <replaceable>VMEM_CAPABILITIES</replaceable> san_ip = <replaceable>VMEM_MGMT_IP</replaceable> san_login = <replaceable>VMEM_USER_NAME</replaceable> san_password = <replaceable>VMEM_PASSWORD</replaceable> use_multipath_for_image_xfer = true </programlisting> </section> <section xml:id="violin-v7k-cfg-vars"> <title>Configuration parameters</title> <para> Description of configuration value placeholders: </para> <variablelist> <varlistentry> <term>VMEM_CAPABILITIES</term> <listitem> <para> User defined capabilities, a JSON formatted string specifying key/value pairs (string value). The ones particularly supported are dedup and thin. Only these two capabilities are listed here in cinder.conf, indicating this backend be selected for creating luns which have a volume type associated with them that have 'dedup' or 'thin' extra_specs specified. For example, if the FSP is configured to support dedup luns, set the associated driver capabilities to: {"dedup":"True","thin":"True"}. </para> </listitem> </varlistentry> <varlistentry> <term>VMEM_MGMT_IP</term> <listitem> <para> External IP address or hostname of the Violin 7300 Memory Gateway. Can be an IP address or hostname. </para> </listitem> </varlistentry> <varlistentry> <term>VMEM_USER_NAME</term> <listitem> <para> Log-in user name for the Violin 7300 Memory Gateway or 7700 FSP controller. This user must have administrative rights on the array or controller. </para> </listitem> </varlistentry> <varlistentry> <term>VMEM_PASSWORD</term> <listitem> <para> Log-in user's password. </para> </listitem> </varlistentry> </variablelist> </section> </section> </section>

commit_message:
Add cluster status check flow for cue-monitor

Change-Id: Ib564c77180a8d31461de5466edb23e20f2966861
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cue refs/changes/87/230287/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Copyright 2015 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import taskflow.patterns.linear_flow as linear_flow import cue.taskflow.task as cue_tasks import os_tasklib.common as os_common def check_node_status(cluster_id, node_number, node_id): """Check Node Status factory function This factory function deletes a flow for deleting a node of a cluster. :param cluster_id: Unique ID for the cluster that the node is part of. :type cluster_id: string :param node_number: Cluster node # for the node being deleted. :type node_number: number :param node_id: Unique ID for the node. :type node_id: string :return: A flow instance that represents the workflow for deleting a cluster node. """ flow_name = "check cluster %s status on node %d" % (cluster_id, node_number) node_name = "cluster[%s].node[%d]" % (cluster_id, node_number) # Extract management ip extract_mgmt_ip = lambda node: node['mgmt_ip'] flow = linear_flow.Flow(flow_name) flow.add( cue_tasks.GetNode( name="Get Node %s" % node_name, inject={'node_id': node_id}, provides="node_%d" % node_number), os_common.Lambda( extract_mgmt_ip, name="extract management ip %s" % node_name, rebind={'node': "node_%d" % node_number}, provides="vm_mgmt_ip_%d" % node_number), cue_tasks.GetRabbitClusterStatus( name="get RabbitMQ status", rebind={'vm_ip': "vm_mgmt_ip_0"}, provides={"node_status_%d" % node_number}, inject={'proto': 'http'}), #TODO(abitha): Update node status ) return flow

commit_message:
Add a pure cinder_backend to configure PureISCSIDriver

This will allow for setting a few configuration options in local.conf
and remove having to specify so much in explicit Cinder and Nova conf 
sections.

Implements: blueprint pure-cinder-backend
Change-Id: I02d7d0cb75b9dc3e3295be1a5c785af20316f8e2

commit_message:
Remove root owned ipsec.secrets for ensure_configs

Since LibreSwan requires that ipsec.secrets be owned by root, the
strategy of rewriting the ipsec.secrets file by writing to a temp file
and renaming causes a permission error and fails to overwrite. This
patch removes the target ipsec.secrets file before running the
ensure_configs operations.

This patch also changes the logging in the _process_running check from
error to info. It isn't an error and will occur under normal
operations.

Change-Id: Id00613e7ca11310e4f65b557b136e02d9783d0d4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas refs/changes/55/231155/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.i18n import _LE, _LI, _LW # Since we set ipsec.secrets to be owned by root, the standard # mechnisms for setting up the config files will get a permission # problem when attempting to overwrite the file, so we need to # remove it first. secrets_file = self._get_config_filename('ipsec.secrets') if os.path.exists(secrets_file): os.remove(secrets_file) # This is logged as "info" instead of error because it simply # means that we couldn't find the files to check on them. LOG.info(_LI('Unable to find control files on startup for ' 'router %(router)s: %(msg)s'), {'router': self.id, 'msg': e})
deleted_lines: from neutron.i18n import _LE, _LW secrets_file = self._get_config_filename('ipsec.secrets') LOG.error(_LE('Unable to check control files on startup for ' 'router %(router)s: %(msg)s'), {'router': self.id, 'msg': e})

commit_message:
Do not log an error when deleting a linuxbridge does not exist

When you're racing to teardown and relying on RPC, it should not be
considered an error that a bridge does not exist when you're trying to
delete it anyway. This is better served as debug level information.

For context, this shows up over 1000 times in successful
gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-linuxbridge job runs in a week so it's
probably safe to say it's not contributing to test failures.

Closes-Bug: #1501779

Change-Id: I8e9b27e010d033291497f4e660a97bbae92e75b1
(cherry picked from commit a9dc48f5a4616a505824c3e8520c3dce7436f1b1)

commit_message:
Workaround potential failure to shutdown services

Kill them twice to make sure they're good'n'dead. There is a supposed
fix to oslo-incubator code, but we're working around that here in the
meantime with this change.

This returned in Liberty.

Change-Id: I02a7af995dc7de857c4efcf2cef2f95d357c007a
Related-Bug: #1446583
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/42/230342/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # TODO(danms): Remove this double-kill when we have # this fixed in all services: # https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+bug/1446583 sleep 1 # /bin/true becakse pkill on a non existant process returns an error pkill -g $(cat $SERVICE_DIR/$SCREEN_NAME/$service.pid) || /bin/true

commit_message:
Clean up the basic install instructions

Moved everything not related to the delorean repos out of
repositories.txt so that it can be reused for the update page.

Changed refrences to discovery image to ironic-python-agent image.

Fixed missing DIB_YUM_REPO_CONF export. The ironic-python-agent
ramdisk can not build without this.

Change-Id: I054dedd7749eac093b24ac1e3e4f4e47fdb41fe2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs refs/changes/47/232147/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #. Use undercloud delorean repos to build the overcloud images: :: export DIB_YUM_REPO_CONF="/etc/yum.repos.d/delorean.repo /etc/yum.repos.d/delorean-deps.repo"
deleted_lines: .. note :: By default, images are built with the latest delorean repository which has passed CI. If you need to manually test packages before CI has passed, you can use: :: export DELOREAN_TRUNK_MGT_REPO="http://trunk.rdoproject.org/centos7/current/"

commit_message:
Remove usage of WritableLogger from oslo_log

With Eventlet 0.17.2, we can directly pass the logger instance. This
allows us to deprecate/remove the WritableLogger class from oslo.log.

Closes-Bug: #1440773
Change-Id: I3985b30b499a1e676d39c2a6cd3a31ac13c0ab47

commit_message:
Document unsearchable_fields configuration option

Although RBAC prevents protected fields appearing in search results, it
cannot prevent searching those fields directly. A long term solution is
a separate admin-only index but for now we add a resource plugin option
'unsearchable_fields' which is comma separated and accepts wildcards as
elasticsearch's mapping_template allows. These fields are turned into
index: no, include_in_all: False mapping templates. The value of this
(plus anything coded into a plugin) is also used to redact fields in
_source for non-administrative users.

This patch provides the documentation update for:
 - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/233225/

Change-Id: I94f47515391cf81d72a6a0d09e7a554259a1f8fb
Partial-Bug: #1504399

added_lines: actions indicated in the tables below... note:: Unless you are changing to a non-default value, you do not need to specify any of the following configuration options. Common Plugin Configuration Options ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ There are common configuration options that all plugins honor. They are split between inheritable configuration options and those that must always be specified individually. **Inheritable Common Configuration Options** Some configuration options may be specified in a default configuration group of ``[resource_plugin]`` in ``searchlight-api.conf`` and optionally overridden in a specific plugin's configuration. For example:: [resource_plugin] index_name = searchlight Inheritable options are listed below: +---------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ | Option | Default value | Description | Action(s) Required | +=====================+===============+=====================================+===========================+ | index_name | searchlight | The ElasticSearch index where the | | Restart services | | | | plugin resource documents will be | | Re-index affected types | | | | stored in. It is recommended to not | | | | | change this unlesss needed. | | +---------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ **Non-Inheritable Common Configuration Options** There are other common configuration options that all plugins honor, but must be specified directly in that plugin's configuration group. They are are not inherited from the ``[resource_plugin]`` configuration group. Non-inheritable options are listed below: +---------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ | Option | Default value | Description | Action(s) Required | +=====================+===============+=====================================+===========================+ | enabled | true | An installed plugin may be enabled | | Restart services | | | | or disabled. When disabled, it will | | Re-index affected types | | | | not be available for bulk indexing, | | | | | notification listening, or | | | | | searching. | | +---------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ | unsearchable_fields | <none> | A comma separated list of fields | | | | | (wildcards allowed) that are stored | | | | | in ElasticSearch, but can not be | | | | | searched on regardless of the | | | | | user's role (admin or not). | | | | | The fields will still be returned | | | | | in search results for admin users, | | | | | but not normal users. These fields | | | | | are typically specified for search | | | | | performance, search accuracy, | | | | | or security reasons. | | +---------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ .. _individual-plugin-configuration:
deleted_lines: Default Plugin Configuration ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ All plugins inherit their configuration from a default configuration group of ``[resource_plugin:default]`` in ``searchlight-api.conf``. For example:: [resource_plugin:default] enabled = true index_name = searchlight The below table shows the available default configuration options. It is only necessary to specify a configuration option in ``searchlight-api.conf`` if you want to use a value other than the default value specified below. +--------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ | Option | Default value | Description | Action(s) Required | +====================+===============+=====================================+===========================+ | enabled | true | An installed plugin may be enabled | | Restart services | | | | or disabled. When disabled, it will | | Re-index affected types | | | | not be available for bulk indexing, | | | | | notification listening, or | | | | | searching. | | +--------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ | index_name | searchlight | The ElasticSearch index where the | | Restart services | | | | plugin resource documents will be | | Re-index affected types | | | | stored in. It is recommended to not | | | | | change this unlesss needed. | | +--------------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+---------------------------+ actions indicated in the table. commit_message:
Update IP Version based on Source/Destination IP Address

IP Version in firewall rules was earlier updated only when --ip-version
was explicitly passed to the firewall-rule-create CLI.Now,based on the version
of the IP Address of the passed Source/Destination, the IP Version field in
firewall rules are automatically updated.Default value is used if no address
is passed to the CLI. Source Address is given higher priority.
This reduces the chance of user providing IPv6 address in source/destination
and the CLI showing IP Version as 4.

Closes Bug:#1497066

Change-Id: Iba708db9bd3afb7485ecaf173a67d4acd60b713d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-fwaas refs/changes/69/228369/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import netaddr def _update_ip_version(self, fwr): # If both source and destination IP are not provided # then default value for ip_version if not fwr['ip_version']: if fwr['source_ip_address']: fwr['ip_version'] = netaddr.IPNetwork( fwr['source_ip_address']).version elif fwr['destination_ip_address']: fwr['ip_version'] = netaddr.IPNetwork( fwr['destination_ip_address']).version self._update_ip_version(fwr)

commit_message:
Improve documentation for Liberty release

The documentation cross linking from the devstack rst to the
individual plugins is missing due to the devstack rst living
in a different directory. We just need to provide a bit better
linking from devstack as well as a bit more info on each plugin
for where to place to the configuration options for each plugin.

There is also opportunity to make the documentation between
plugins more consistent and provide release note information.

Change-Id: Ib64eeda8a9f5b59777135537de60f049952a4660
Closes-Bug: #1500647
(cherry picked from commit 7079f81421ae94e7e26816ad6097d9753062ad35)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/searchlight refs/changes/57/233257/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The search service determines the type of information that is indexed and searchable via a plugin mechanism. See :ref:`searchlight-plugins` for plugin installation and general configuration information. See each plugin below for detailed information about specific plugins:To initially create the catalog index (or add new resource typs to it later), run the following command::This will iterate through all registered and enabled search plugins and request that they perform a full indexing of all data that's available to them.You will be prompted to confirm unless ``--force`` is provided. The ``searchlight-manage index sync`` command may be re-run at any time to perform a full re-index of the data. This will delete the data, any mappings, and recreate them from scratch, which means temporary data unavailability. Zero downtime full re-indexing will be implemented in a future release. For now, you may use the ``--no-delete`` option to update existing data and add new data. This does have the side effect of leaving behind resource data that may no longer exist in the source service, so should only be used as a supplement for services that do not produce intermediate status change notifications. For example, in the Liberty release, the Glance service did not provide image membership update notifications, even though it provided image update and delete notifications. In order to provide accurate membership information, a cron job could be set up with the following command to get the most up to date information for indexed images:: searchlight-manage index sync --type OS::Glance::Image --force --no-deleteincremental updates rather than re-index the entire data set again. The preferred methodolgy is to set up notification listening.
deleted_lines: The search service determines the types of information that is searchable via a plugin mechanism. Within ``setup.cfg`` the setting within ``[entry_points]`` named ``searchlight.index_backend`` should list the available indexable types. After making a change, it's necessary to reinstall the python package (for instance with ``pip install -e .``). Each plugin registered in ``setup.cfg`` is enabled by default. Typically it should only be necessary to modify ``setup.cfg`` if you are adding a new plugin. Installed plugins can be disabled, enabled and configured in the ``searchlight-api.conf`` file. .. warning:: After making changes to ``searchlight-api.conf`` you must restart all running ``searchlight-api`` *and* ``searchlight-listener`` processes. After enabling a plugin or changing ``index_name`` you will need to reindex any changed resources. Default configuration values may be set for all plugins using the following in ``searchlight-api.conf``:: [resource_plugin:default] index_name = searchlight See each plugin below for detailed information:To initially create the catalog index (or add to it later), run the following command::This will iterate through all registered search plugins and request that they index all data that's available to them. This command may be re-run at any time to perform a full re-index.You will be prompted to confirm unless --force is provided.incremental updates rather than re-index the entire data set again.

commit_message:
disable port_security for VRRP ports

For tenant networks port_security makes sense, but for the VRRP router
case it can get in the way. This change disables it for Akanda managed
ports for now.

Change-Id: I0fb9fd5253ad0538a35b25d8806323f83cfc48e4
Closes-bug: #1482389

commit_message:
Don't index admin-only fields

Although RBAC prevents protected fields appearing in search results, it
cannot prevent searching those fields directly. A long term solution is
a separate admin-only index but for now we add a resource plugin option
'unsearchable_fields' which is comma separated and accepts wildcards as
elasticsearch's mapping_template allows. These fields are turned into
index: no, include_in_all: False mapping templates. The value of this
(plus anything coded into a plugin) is also used to redact fields in
_source for non-administrative users.

Documentation update in a separate patch.

Change-Id: Ie5bd3fa55ff43fd1a6f52478866261734bd7a051
Closes-Bug: #1504399
(cherry picked from commit fb61e54f00c5f0a750235d3b2fc737d46d50aab5)

added_lines: # Will be combined with 'unsearchable_fields' from config UNSEARCHABLE_FIELDS = ['OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:*'] def unsearchable_fields(self): from_conf = super(ServerIndex, self).unsearchable_fields return ServerIndex.UNSEARCHABLE_FIELDS + from_conf @property def facets_with_options(self): return ('OS-EXT-AZ:availability_zone', return {'tenant_id': True,
deleted_lines: import re # Properties restricted to admins only. hostId seems not to be # considered sensitive because it doesn't directly identify hosts, # just whether your VMs are cohabiting ADMIN_ONLY_PROPERTIES = u'(OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:.*)$' 'OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:host': { 'type': 'string', 'index': 'not_analyzed' }, def facets_with_options(self): return ('OS-EXT-AZ:availability_zone', 'OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:host', return {'OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:host': True, 'tenant_id': True, def filter_result(self, hit, request_context): if not request_context.is_admin: source = hit['_source'] for key in list(source.keys()): if re.match(self.ADMIN_ONLY_PROPERTIES, key): del hit['_source'][key]

commit_message:
Cleaned up remaining incorrect usage for LOG.exception

- callers should not explicitly pass exceptions into LOG.exception
  because it's already implicitly included in the message by stdlib
  logging module.
- callers should not call to LOG.exception when there is no exception to
  log about (known to fail in Python 3.x < 3.5).

Change-Id: I58e7e01ed152028ad43bb3ada87d719caa2ab08d
Related-Bug: #1504053

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-09 17:44:08.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/plugin.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/5a4e353c5845e4dc1cdbeeee1ac81052db38237e', 'message': 'Explicitly install tox

When testing OVN with Kuryr using a setup which only installs Neutron,
keystone, mysql and OVN, the devstack run fails because tox is not
installed. It was being pulled in when installing tempest. Since
networking-ovn uses genconfig to generate a config file, make sure
we install this ourselves.

With this run, my devstack with Kuryr works now.

Signed-off-by: Kyle Mestery <mestery@mestery.com>

commit_message:
Explicitly install tox

When testing OVN with Kuryr using a setup which only installs Neutron,
keystone, mysql and OVN, the devstack run fails because tox is not
installed. It was being pulled in when installing tempest. Since
networking-ovn uses genconfig to generate a config file, make sure
we install this ourselves.

With this run, my devstack with Kuryr works now.

Change-Id: I67afce78152f250920ef43334e7ee87440bcd075
Signed-off-by: Kyle Mestery <mestery@mestery.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/95/233195/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Install tox, used to generate the config pip_install tox

added_lines: def _is_boot_disk(self, disk): for vol in disk['volumes']: if vol['type'] == 'pv' and vol['vg'] == 'os' and vol['size'] > 0: return True if self._is_boot_disk(disk): # we install bootloader on every disk LOG.debug('Adding bootloader stage0 on disk %s' % disk['name']) parted.install_bootloader = True # legacy boot partition LOG.debug('Adding bios_grub partition on disk %s: size=24' % disk['name']) parted.add_partition(size=24, flags=['bios_grub']) # uefi partition (for future use) LOG.debug('Adding UEFI partition on disk %s: size=200' % disk['name']) parted.add_partition(size=200) and self._is_boot_disk(disk):

Adapt functional tests to pika-driver

In this patch conf object passing through the fixtures to
objects is added

Also conf.prog and conf.project attributes are initialized
for tests

Partial-Implements: bp rabbit-pika

commit_message:
Tuskar role components spec

Change-Id: I08e6722877d1fbee8cb49145e436bfcc49405181
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/55/133755/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================== Tuskar Role Components ====================== Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/tuskar-role-components The TripleO Heat Templates are in the process of being refactored to use separately defined Heat SoftwareConfig and SoftwareDeployment resources. Tuskar needs to be updated to allow for the usage of these when configuring a role. Problem Description =================== Tuskar currently assumes each role is completely defined in a single Heat template. The THT templates are moving in a direction where certain pieces of the definition are being extracted into their own template files (there is currently no spec which describes this process or its intended scope). When creating the overcloud, the resource_registry determines which of these extracted files are used by the resource. An example can be seen at: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/130303/ That example covers extracting the NovaComputeConfig definition out of compute.yaml and into a separate file. Instead of the full configuration definition, the compute.yaml template simply creates a resource of type ``OS::TripleO::NovaComputeConfig``. It is up to the resource_registry to map this namespace to an appropriate template. Tuskar needs to provide: * Storage of these extracted templates. * Retrieval of these template names from Tuskar. * The ability for a user to add one of these templates to a plan and provide the namespace under which it is added. Proposed Change =============== Overview -------- Tuskar will introduce a new concept called a **role component**. A role component corresponds to a Heat template. Typically, a role component template will only contain a ``SoftwareConfig`` or ``SoftwareDeployment`` (or their ``Structured`` counterparts). Initially, role components will be added using the ``tuskar-load-roles`` script (or a new script that functions similarly). A separate spec will be filed to add create/update/delete operations through the REST API. User Workflow ^^^^^^^^^^^^^ * The user adds a role to a plan. * When retrieving the plan, the user will be provided with a list of unmapped namespaces. * The user retrieves a list of role components from Tuskar. * The user assigns a role component to each of the unmapped namespaces and saves the information in Tuskar. * Tuskar stores the mappings in the plan's ``resource_registry`` entry. Details ^^^^^^^ Tuskar will determine unmapped namespaces for a role by inspecting the role's template. Any resource whose type matches ``OS::TripleO`` will be flagged as needing a mapping. The plan's ``resource_registry`` will be checked to see if any of those namespaces are already fulfilled and those that are not are considered to be unmapped. REST API Changes ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ .. _list-role-components: **Retrieving Role Components** URL: ``/role-components/`` Method: ``GET`` Description: Returns a list of available role components in Tuskar. Notes: * There will be a separate entry for each version of a particular role component. Request Data: None Response Codes: * 200 - containing the available role components Response Data: A list of role components, where each contains: * UUID * Name * Version * Description Response Example: .. code-block:: json [ { "uuid" : "3d46e510-6a63-4ed1-abd0-9306a451f8b4", "name" : "compute-config", "version" : "1", "description" : "Software Config for compute nodes." }, { "uuid" : "71d6c754-c89c-4293-9d7b-c4dcc57229f0", "name" : "controller-config", "version" : "1", "description" : "Software Config for controller nodes." }, ] ---- .. _add-plan-role-component: **Adding a Role Component to a Plan** URL: ``/plans/<plan-uuid/role-components/`` Method: ``POST`` Description: Adds a role component to the given plan. Notes: * This call will update the ``last_modified`` timestamp to indicate a change has been made that will require an update to Heat to be made live. Request Data: JSON document containing the following: * Namespace - Indicates the namespace the component is fulfilling. * UUID - Identifies the component being added. Request Example: .. code-block:: json { "namespace" : "OS::TripleO::NovaComputeConfig", "uuid" : "role_component_uuid" } Response Codes: * 201 - if the addition is successful * 400 - if there is no role component with the given UUID * 404 - if there is no plan with the given UUID .. note:: For simplicity, the ``POST`` will not return a 409 if the namespace is already mapped. This call can be used to change the component for a given namespace if it has already been defined. Response Data: The same document describing the plan as from :ref:`Retrieve a Single Plan <retrieve-single-plan>`. Alternatives ------------ There are currently no alternate proposals. Security Impact --------------- These changes should have no additional security impact. Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ There is no added performance that were not already addressed by the storage and assignment of roles. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- In addition to adding roles to Tuskar at installation time, role components will also need to be added. This will look similar to loading roles (through a script). Developer Impact ---------------- Once this feature lands, the role components will need to be loaded into existing developer installations. At the time of writing, the template changes that split out the configs are already starting to land, which will break Tuskar before this feature lands. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jdob Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Implement storage of role components * Implement role component loading mechanism * Implement role component retrieval REST API * Implement role component assignment REST API * Implement logic for determining unmapped namespaces in a role Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Tests will be added similar to the role loading and assignment tests. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation must be written for the following: * The new REST API calls * The changes to the installation process to load the component roles References ========== None

commit_message:
Add sample for Linux bridge, fix Linux bond sample

This change adds a sample template for Linux bridge bridges. It also
fixes the indentation in the Linux bond sample template.

Change-Id: Ifc0244bd2fdce67f8b2fca4017775265f0bc5ce0

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-09 19:08:07.000000000', 'files': ['searchlight/tests/functional/test_listener.py', 'searchlight/tests/functional/test_load.py', 'searchlight/tests/functional/test_api.py', 'searchlight/tests/unit/test_nova_server_plugin.py', 'searchlight/elasticsearch/plugins/base.py', 'searchlight/elasticsearch/plugins/glance/images.py', 'searchlight/elasticsearch/plugins/nova/servers.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/searchlight/commit/fb61e54f00c5f0a750235d3b2fc737d46d50aab5', 'message': "Don't index admin-only fields

Although RBAC prevents protected fields appearing in search results, it
cannot prevent searching those fields directly. A long term solution is
a separate admin-only index but for now we add a resource plugin option
'unsearchable_fields' which is comma separated and accepts wildcards as
elasticsearch's mapping_template allows. These fields are turned into

Change-Id: Ie5bd3fa55ff43fd1a6f52478866261734bd7a051
Closes-Bug: #1504399

commit_message:
Don't index admin-only fields

Although RBAC prevents protected fields appearing in search results, it
cannot prevent searching those fields directly. A long term solution is
a separate admin-only index but for now we add a resource plugin option
'unsearchable_fields' which is comma separated and accepts wildcards as
elasticsearch's mapping_template allows. These fields are turned into
index: no, include_in_all: False mapping templates. The value of this
(plus anything coded into a plugin) is also used to redact fields in
_source for non-administrative users.

Documentation update in a separate patch.

Change-Id: Ie5bd3fa55ff43fd1a6f52478866261734bd7a051
Closes-Bug: #1504399
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/searchlight refs/changes/25/233225/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Will be combined with 'unsearchable_fields' from config UNSEARCHABLE_FIELDS = ['OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:*'] def unsearchable_fields(self): from_conf = super(ServerIndex, self).unsearchable_fields return ServerIndex.UNSEARCHABLE_FIELDS + from_conf @property def facets_with_options(self): return ('OS-EXT-AZ:availability_zone', return {'tenant_id': True,
deleted_lines: import re # Properties restricted to admins only. hostId seems not to be # considered sensitive because it doesn't directly identify hosts, # just whether your VMs are cohabiting ADMIN_ONLY_PROPERTIES = u'(OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:.*)$' 'OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:host': { 'type': 'string', 'index': 'not_analyzed' }, def facets_with_options(self): return ('OS-EXT-AZ:availability_zone', 'OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:host', return {'OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:host': True, 'tenant_id': True, def filter_result(self, hit, request_context): if not request_context.is_admin: source = hit['_source'] for key in list(source.keys()): if re.match(self.ADMIN_ONLY_PROPERTIES, key): del hit['_source'][key]

commit_message:
Add Ceilometer configuration ttl setting for expirer

The Ceilometer expirer tool depends on the TTL configuration option to
determine the time-to-live of samples in the Ceilometer database.

Change-Id: I5ac2f7983db1f9342bbba2840effb21964bef3c1
Relies-on: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/126607/
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/06/126606/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: time_to_live={{ceilometer.expirer_ttl}}

commit_message:
Containerized TripleO Overcloud.

This change adds a containerized version of the overcloud compute node for
TripleO.  It's still a work in progress but I figured I'd put it up so people
can comment on how they want to see this advance.  Please see the
README-containers.md file for more information on how to set this up.

This uses AtomicOS as a base operating system and requires that we bootstrap
the image with a container which contains the os-* programs.

Change-Id: I8bbe75abc3f5e160bd4371710cbac236ba8eebc9
Co-Authored-By: Ryan Hallisey <rhallise@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

In OpenStack Infra, we would like to run Puppet unit tests that
sometimes depends on other Puppet OpenStack modules.
Example: a patch in puppet-openstacklib that needs to be tested in puppet-nova.

This patch modifies the Rakefile to:
* clean spec_prep and spec_clean Rake tasks
* use openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/install_modules_unit.sh script
  to clone modules.
* do not use .fixtures.yaml file to clone modules and rely on
  zuul-cloner or git.
* Add openstack/ in gitignore so we never commit the
  puppet-openstack-integration repository (can happen when spec_clean
  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross
modules like we do with functional testing.

Change-Id: I80dd7e183098d7265ac52da4445c1963dace7ffb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tempest refs/changes/88/232788/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: gem 'r10k', :require => 'false'

commit_message:
Make keepalived virtual router IDs configurable

Make the virtual router IDs configurable for the VRRP instances
associated with the Controller VIP or the Public VIP. This allows
side-by-side installations to work, as otherwise, the keepalived
clusters will interfere with each other and ultimately result in
failure to bring up a VIP.

Closes-Bug: 1396695
Co-authored-by: James Polley <jp@jamezpolley.com>
Change-Id: I659c116477d5a99ee6537e0fea80fdee7eaad909

commit_message:
Add metadata and change swift.devices to enable zones

This change adds metadata swift.zones and a corresponding
parameter SwiftZones to set the number of Swift zones to be used
when building the overcloud.  This number defaults to 1.  In
addition we change the swift.devices metadata to include the
server key - of the form controller|SwiftStorage<N> - between %-signs
which is used by the modified element
swift/os-refresh-config/configure.d/73-swift to place the server
in the appropriate zone.

Change-Id: I0e0f5189da1575f2e1ed7fba4bbbe13a8fbf6221
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/58/97758/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add Ceilometer configuration ttl setting for expirer

Adds the ttl settings for the Ceilometer expirer tool, defaulting to the
"-1" (retain all) value for the time-to-live for samples in the Ceilometer
database.

Change-Id: I6c7d4cb691c531fd7131e6c09235fe8074063191
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/07/126607/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CeilometerExpirerTTL: default: -1 description: Time (in minutes) to retain ceilometer sample data. type: number hidden: false expirer_ttl: {get_param: CeilometerExpirerTTL}

commit_message:
Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

In OpenStack Infra, we would like to run Puppet unit tests that
sometimes depends on other Puppet OpenStack modules.
Example: a patch in puppet-openstacklib that needs to be tested in puppet-nova.

This patch modifies the Rakefile to:
* clean spec_prep and spec_clean Rake tasks
* use openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/install_modules_unit.sh script
  to clone modules.
* do not use .fixtures.yaml file to clone modules and rely on
  zuul-cloner or git.
* Add openstack/ in gitignore so we never commit the
  puppet-openstack-integration repository (can happen when spec_clean
  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross
modules like we do with functional testing.

Change-Id: Ie3476db0bcc7f4ab08d64dd63e71958e8b3f5ab2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-zaqar refs/changes/93/232793/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: gem 'r10k', :require => 'false'

subject: Add SwiftRingBuild parameter
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-24 09:19:30.000000000', 'files': ['swift-storage-source.yaml', 'swift-deploy.yaml', 'swift-source.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/36cee2257cdfbf3a2c44cf12c3f5095214ecccfe', 'message': 'Add SwiftRingBuild parameter

We want to add the facility to disable Swift ring building on nodes
running Swift.  To do this we add a parameter called SwiftRingBuild.
If this parameter is set to False or F, then the swift element will
not attempt to build the rings.  If this parameter is set to True
(the default) or T then the swift element will build the rings.

We want to allow an operator to turn off ring-building in the case
where new Swift nodes are being added to an existing Swift cluster.
In the absence of any tooling to help with ring management the
operator will have to use the default method of building new rings
to include the new nodes, and distributing the rings to the Swift
nodes - including existing nodes.

There is a corresponding element change, see
https://review.openstack.org/109029

Change-Id: I01311ec3ca265b151f8740bf7dc57cdf0cf0df6f
'}]
commit_message:
Add SwiftRingBuild parameter

We want to add the facility to disable Swift ring building on nodes
running Swift.  To do this we add a parameter called SwiftRingBuild.
If this parameter is set to False or F, then the swift element will
not attempt to build the rings.  If this parameter is set to True
(the default) or T then the swift element will build the rings.

We want to allow an operator to turn off ring-building in the case
where new Swift nodes are being added to an existing Swift cluster.
In the absence of any tooling to help with ring management the
operator will have to use the default method of building new rings
to include the new nodes, and distributing the rings to the Swift
nodes - including existing nodes.

There is a corresponding element change, see
https://review.openstack.org/109029

Change-Id: I01311ec3ca265b151f8740bf7dc57cdf0cf0df6f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/25/109225/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ring-build: { get_input: swift_ring_build }

subject: Add ironic_base test case
revisions:

commit_message:
Add ironic_base test case

 Scenario:
  1. Create cluster
  2. Add 1 controller node
  3. Add 1 compute node
  4. Add 1 ironic node
  5. Launch OSTF tests

Partially Implements: blueprint fuel-integrate-ironic

Change-Id: I3a5b15f61d41ab7936de684166eacd542c00e0de

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-10-08 22:06:51.000000000', 'files': ['.gitignore', '.fixtures.yml', 'Rakefile', 'Gemfile'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-mistral/commit/b61deb52f2697f38a84420370540e2155d57348a', 'message': "Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

modules like we do with functional testing.

commit_message:
Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

In OpenStack Infra, we would like to run Puppet unit tests that
sometimes depends on other Puppet OpenStack modules.
Example: a patch in puppet-openstacklib that needs to be tested in puppet-nova.

This patch modifies the Rakefile to:
* clean spec_prep and spec_clean Rake tasks
* use openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/install_modules_unit.sh script
  to clone modules.
* do not use .fixtures.yaml file to clone modules and rely on
  zuul-cloner or git.
* Add openstack/ in gitignore so we never commit the
  puppet-openstack-integration repository (can happen when spec_clean
  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross
modules like we do with functional testing.

Change-Id: Id00869faee250e37b7217357e39bc5fbda567a55
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-mistral refs/changes/80/232780/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: gem 'r10k', :require => 'false'

Puppetfile: add latest created modules

Update Puppetfile with latest modules that have recently been added to
OpenStack forge.

Change-Id: I9597882167bb00cae57be0e7e3b90b498aab2f29

subject: Docker compute role configured via Puppet
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-05 12:59:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/7def4006634592da9287b308d5219207e024bd32', 'message': 'Docker compute role configured via Puppet

This change adds a containerized version of the overcloud compute node for
TripleO. Configuration files are generated via OpenStack Puppet modules
which are then used to externally configure kolla containers for
each OpenStack service.

See the README-containers.md file for more information on how to set this up.

This uses AtomicOS as a base operating system and requires that we bootstrap
the image with a container which contains the required os-collect-config agent
hooks to support running puppet, shell scripts, and docker compose.

Change-Id: Ic8331f52b20a041803a9d74cdf0eb81266d4e03c
Co-Authored-By: Ian Main <imain@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Docker compute role configured via Puppet

This change adds a containerized version of the overcloud compute node for
TripleO. Configuration files are generated via OpenStack Puppet modules
which are then used to externally configure kolla containers for
each OpenStack service.

See the README-containers.md file for more information on how to set this up.

This uses AtomicOS as a base operating system and requires that we bootstrap
the image with a container which contains the required os-collect-config agent
hooks to support running puppet, shell scripts, and docker compose.

Change-Id: Ic8331f52b20a041803a9d74cdf0eb81266d4e03c
Co-Authored-By: Ian Main <imain@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Ryan Hallisey <rhallise@redhat.com>

name: result config: {get_file: ./copy-etc.sh} CopyEtcDeployment: type: OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployments depends_on: ComputePuppetDeployment properties: config: {get_resource: CopyEtcConfig} servers: {get_param: servers} NovaComputeContainersDeployment: type: OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployments depends_on: [CopyEtcDeployment, ComputePuppetDeployment] properties: config: {get_resource: NovaComputeContainersConfig} servers: {get_param: servers} NovaComputeContainersConfig: type: OS::Heat::StructuredConfig properties: group: docker-compose config: computedata: image: {get_param: DockerComputeDataImage} name: computedata libvirt: image: {get_param: DockerLibvirtImage} name: libvirt net: host pid: host privileged: true restart: always volumes: - commit_message:
Provide minimum VIOS connection on vSCSI volumes

When the admin attempts to connect a volume, they may wish to specify a
minimum level of redundancy (how many Virtual I/O Servers it connects
to).  This change set provides the operator with the ability to set a
minimum number of VIOSes.

Change-Id: Id4d4ca945190f04436792cac12fa08f4412bc114
Closes-Bug: 1504037
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/38/232738/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Check the number of VIOSes vioses_modified = 0 for result in ret['wrapper_task_rets'].values(): if result['vio_modified']: vioses_modified += 1 self._validate_vios_on_connection(vioses_modified) def _validate_vios_on_connection(self, num_vioses_found): """Validates that the correct number of VIOSes were discovered. Certain environments may have redundancy requirements. For PowerVM this is achieved by having multiple Virtual I/O Servers. This method will check to ensure that the operators requirements for redundancy have been met. If not, a specific error message will be raised. :param num_vioses_found: The number of VIOSes the hdisk was found on. """ # Is valid as long as the vios count exceeds the conf value. if num_vioses_found >= CONF.powervm.vscsi_vios_connections_required: return # Should have a custom message based on zero or 'some but not enough' # I/O Servers. if num_vioses_found == 0: else: msg = (_('Failed to discover the hdisk on the required number of ' 'Virtual I/O Servers. Volume %(volume_id)s required ' '%(vios_req)d Virtual I/O Servers, but the disk was only ' 'found on %(vios_act)d Virtual I/O Servers.') % {'volume_id': self.volume_id, 'vios_act': num_vioses_found, 'vios_req': CONF.powervm.vscsi_vios_connections_required}) LOG.error(msg) ex_args = {'volume_id': self.volume_id, 'reason': msg, 'instance_name': self.instance.name} raise p_exc.VolumeAttachFailed(**ex_args)
deleted_lines: # If no valid hdisk was found, log and exit if not any([result['vio_modified'] for result in ret['wrapper_task_rets'].values()]): LOG.error(msg) ex_args = {'volume_id': self.volume_id, 'reason': msg, 'instance_name': self.instance.name} raise p_exc.VolumeAttachFailed(**ex_args)

commit_message:
Remove openstack_deploy from teardown.sh deletion list

This patch prevents teardown.sh script from deleting
/etc/openstack_deploy in order to let the deployer decide whether to
delete it or not.

Change-Id: I8de55c6fce79bd9301d995c565cfb4e0a38b253a
Closes-Bug: #1504561

subject: Update dhcp host portbinding on failover
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-09 05:45:36.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/api/rpc/handlers/dhcp_rpc.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/api/rpc/handlers/test_dhcp_rpc.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/9950ce2bbc5a554c211935a6652c304937d39195', 'message': "Update dhcp host portbinding on failover

When a dhcp server is moved to new host on failover,
tunnel is not created.

When a dhcp server is moved to new host,
1) network-hostagent binding is updated(properly i.e with new host).
2) dhcp port-hostagent binding is not updated
   ( dhcp port is still bound to old host)
If dhcp port-bound agent is different from the new dhcp agent
(which is now taking care of this dhcp port), neutron plugin won't
 notify the l2pop, and hence tunnel is not created.

As after failover, the new agent is taking care of this dhcp port,
update portbinding with the new host. This will allow neutron plugin
to notify l2pop(which will create tunnel).

Change-Id: Ib7d7dcddee005395af116ccd31a43853332ae317
Closes-bug: #1411163
(cherry picked from commit 571453c614577ffd47e23de9a35863d2f2119583)
"}]
commit_message:
Update dhcp host portbinding on failover

When a dhcp server is moved to new host on failover,
tunnel is not created.

When a dhcp server is moved to new host,
1) network-hostagent binding is updated(properly i.e with new host).
2) dhcp port-hostagent binding is not updated
   ( dhcp port is still bound to old host)
If dhcp port-bound agent is different from the new dhcp agent
(which is now taking care of this dhcp port), neutron plugin won't
 notify the l2pop, and hence tunnel is not created.

As after failover, the new agent is taking care of this dhcp port,
update portbinding with the new host. This will allow neutron plugin
to notify l2pop(which will create tunnel).

Change-Id: Ib7d7dcddee005395af116ccd31a43853332ae317
Closes-bug: #1411163
(cherry picked from commit 571453c614577ffd47e23de9a35863d2f2119583)
